summary:
Rome is remains the dominant power in the West, but it is the beginning of the end for the behemoth. Four years ago Emperor Julian allowed the Franks to become the first foederatii, a Germanic tribe residing in the Empire, but allowed to keep its own government. In the years following, this precedent would lead to other several other foederatii being established. This technique made for easy peace in the short term, but would eventually give the Germanic tribes a strong foothold within Rome.

As Rome’s defenses received their first small puncture, the Goths were establishing their own empire in Eastern Europe under the rule King Ermanarich. The tide was beginning to turn against Rome, but first an unexpected surprise from the East…

It has been a bad time for Europe. 34 years ago the late King Ermanarich delved too deep in his conquests and awakened the Huns. After they realized how easily their mounted archers could defeat Germanic cavalry, the Huns rushed into Eastern Europe like a tsunami, displacing and enslaving tribes as they went. In only three years, the Huns conquered nearly half of the Germanic lands. This was the beginning of a series of events that would change the face of Europe.

Those who were not enslaved fled to Rome. Rome tried to resist, but after its legions were crushed at the Battle of Adrianople, they realized that they were too weak to defend against the Germanic cavalry, so they began supplementing their forces with Germanic mercenaries. By the time on the map right now, most of the Roman forces were paid mercenaries, and even the commander of the army, Stilicho the Vandal, was a mercenary general. These mercenary forces have had moderate success in pushing back the Germanic tribes and keeping them at bay for the last 30 years, but now many of the tribes have united, and Rome is about to realize how fickle the allegiance of mercenaries can be…
